question: To Fort William Henry. It should be enough to remind you France is the enemy.
answer: Your enemy ...

question: What did you say?
answer: I said ... France is your enemy. Not ours.

question: Really? Do you want them to overrun all New York colony?
answer: First place, you started it with the French over fur-trapping claims to the head waters of the Ohio. Now you're sayin' these people have a fight on their hands ...

question: Will you men help us stop the French?
answer: ... and while they are cooped up in your fort, what if the French send war parties to raid their homes?

question: Major Duncan Heyward reporting, Sir!
answer: Duncan. How was your journey?

question: I didn't experience anything so surprising from Bristol to Albany as what I witnessed here today.
answer: And what is that?

question: The Crown "negotiating" the terms of service?
answer: I know. One has to give Americans "reasons" and make agreements to get them to do anything at all. Tiring, isn't it? But that's the way of it here.

question: I thought British policy is 'Make the World ... England', sir.
answer: You will take command of the 62nd Regiment of Foot. At Fort William Henry under Colonel Munro. I will march the 33rd to Fort Edward.

question: Sir! ... Might I enquire if General Webb has heard from Colonel Munro's daughters? I was to rendezvous with them in Albany and escort them to the fort.
answer: Yes. You may. You there. What does Munro call you? The "Scotsman" has sent one of his Indian allies to guide you.

question: Dawn. At the encampment. Six a.m. sharp. See to it you're there. My God it's good to see you.
answer: I'm embarrassed to be so indecisive ... after so long apart and after you've traveled so far ...

question: And by sea!
answer: You still have an aversion to the water?

question: Aversion? No. ... "Hatred" ... "Loathing" ... But it was worth it all to end in a garden by your side.
answer: Dear Duncan, my affection is as towards a closest friend. Alice and I depend on you and respect you immensely ... I wish they did, but my feelings don't go beyond that. Do you see?

question: Isn't respect and friendship, a reasonable basis for a man and woman to be joined? And all else may grow in time ...?
answer: Some say that's the way of it.

question: "Some"?
answer: Cousin Eugenie, my father, but ...

question: Cora, in my heart, I know once we're joined, we'll be the happiest couple in England. Let those whom you trust, your father, help settle what's best for you. In view of your indecision, why not rely on their advice and judgment as well as mine? Will you consider that?
answer: Yes. Yes, I will.

question: Absolutely. You there, Scout! We must ... stop ... soon. Women are ... tired. You ... understand?
answer: I understand. This is not good place to stop. Two leagues from here. No water 'til then. That where we stop. Better place.

question: No. Stop in the glade just ahead! When the ladies are rested, we will proceed. Do you understand?
answer: "Magua understand paleface is a dog to his women. When his women want to eat, he lay aside his tomahawk to feed their laziness."

question: Excuse me. What did you say?
answer: Magua say

question: ... take you as far as the fort. If we are goin' to take you, we need to move. Fast ... And the fort is well off our course. So if you all rather wait for the next Huron war party to come by, we'll be on our way.
answer: conforms. He's ill at ease not being in command, following the lead of some half-Indian frontiersman through a foreign wilderness.] How far is it, scout?

question: Day and a half Where did you get ... the guide?
answer: Colonel Munro sent him. He was one of our Mohawk allies.

question: He is Huron and nothing else. Why would he want to murder the girl?
answer: What?!

question: Dark haired ...
answer: Miss Cora Munro. He never set eyes on her before today.

question: No blood vengeance? No re-proach or insult?
answer: Of course not! And how is it you were nearby?

question: Came across the war party, tracked 'em.
answer: Then you're assigned to Fort William Henry?

question: No.
answer: Fort Edward, then?

question: No. Headin' west. To Can-tuck-ee.
answer: I thought all our colonial scouts were in the militia?

question: I ain't your "scout". And I am in no damn militia.
answer: Then you are one of those who would allow England to fight alone while she protects you from France?

question: England does not protect me and does not war against France on our account. She uses us to war against France on her own account ... of greed for land and furs. Clear it up any?
answer: I owe you gratitude or I'd call you out!

question: Though they are strangers, they are at least entitled to a Christian burial!
answer: Let us go, miss.

question: I will not. I have seen the face of war before, Mr. Poe, but never war made on women and children. And almost as cruel is your indifference.
answer: Miss Munro. They are not strangers .... And they stay as they lay ...!

question: throws Heyward a blanket. Heyward spreads the blanket below the top of the mound and - maintaining silence - he gestures for Cora & Alice to rest there. doesn't react as Cora enters. He's scanning the trees; not looking at her. They whisper ...
answer: Why didn't you bury those people?

question: Anyone lookin' to pick up our trail, would see it as a sign of our passing ...
answer: You knew them. You were acting for our benefit. And I apologize. I misunderstood you.

question: Well that is to be expected. My father ...
answer: Your "father"?

question: Chingachgook. He warned me about people like you.
answer: He did?

question: Yes. He said ... "do not try to make them understand you."
answer: What?!

question: on his back, his tomahawk within reach on the ground.
answer: His massive arms spread revealing his war club in his left fist; his fusil in his right hand.

question: waiting for the attack. Cora's eyes are anxious, but there's no terror there. Nathaniel's impressed with her cool. He hands her a pistol. She takes it. He listens for the soft drop of moccasined feet ...
answer: sees all of it; doesn't like it.

question: The Ottawa are gone.
answer: Why did they turn back? turns and makes out stilt platforms of skeletons and torn strips of buckskin silhouetted against the night sky in the distance. They have camped on sanctified ground, a burial place. "We're a breed apart and we make no sense" ...?

question: In your particular case, miss, I would make some allowance ...
answer: Thank you so much. You called Chingachgook your "father"? Where is your real family?

question: They buried my ma & pa and my sisters. And Chingachgook - who found me with two French trappers - raised me up as his own.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: I do not remember them. I was one or two.
answer: How did you learn English?

question: My father sent Uncas & I to Reverend Wheelock's school when I was ten. So we would know both worlds ... though we were told only bother learning readin' & arithmetic from yous.
answer: And what were the consequentialities of European culture you didn't bother with?

question: The Bible. Monarchy. Many wrong ideas about the government of men. My father's people already know each man is his own nation. And only he can have dominion over himself. Not kings. No man is better than any other man.
answer: In London those radical ideas could land you in Newgate prison. Why were those people living in this defenseless place ...?

question: 'Cos frontier land's the only land affordable to poor people. So after seven years indentured service in Virginia, they headed out here where they are beholden to none and not livin' by another's leave ... Their name was Cameron. John & Alexandria. My father's people say ... at the birth of the sun and of his brother, the moon, their mother died ... so the sun gave to the earth her body, from which was to spring all life. And he drew forth from her breast the stars. The stars he threw into the night sky to remind him of her soul. So there is the Camerons' monument ... my folks', too, I guess.
answer: You are right, Mr. Poe. We do not understand what is happening here. And it is not as I imagined it would be, thinking of it in Boston and London ...

question: Sorry to disappoint you ...
answer: On the contrary. It is more deeply stirring ... to my blood ... ... than any imagining could possibly have been ... Much further?

question: Why are you here?! Why did you allow them to come? ... And where the bloody hell are my reinforcements!! Told you to stay away from this hell hole! Why did you disobey me?
answer: When? How?

question: My letter ...
answer: There was none!

question: What?
answer: There was no letter.

question: Does Webb not even know we are besieged?
answer: Sir. Webb has no idea. And he certainly does not know to send reinforcements!

question: What happened to you?
answer: Ambush ... on the George Road. This Magua led us into it. ... eighteen killed. It's these men who saved us. They guided us here ...

question: is moved beyond words by his daughters' presence. There's a break, a pause ... What a place for them ...
answer: Might I enquire after the situation, sir, given that I've seen of the French engineering from the ridge above?

question: Logistics are his guns are bigger than mine and he has more of them. They keep our heads down while his sappers make thirty yards of trench a day. His thirteen inch mortars have a two hundred yard range, so when they're close enough, they'll move them in, lob explosive rounds over our walls and pound us to dust.
answer: They look to be three hundred yards out. You have three days.

question: ... not enough time to get to Albany and back with reinforcements ...
answer: Webb's not in Albany. He marched the 33rd to Fort Edward two days ago.

question: Webb's at Edward?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Only twelve miles away! He could be here day after tomorrow. Find your man, sir! Captain Beams will give you the message.
answer: John Cameron's cabin. We come upon it last night. Burned out. Everyone murdered. And it was Ottawa. They're allied to the French.

question: Yes, Mr. Poe? So?
answer: It was a war party. It means they're on the attack up and down the frontier.

question: Thank you.
answer: Many men here, their homes are in the path.

question: stands with a huge and fearsome elaborately tattooed and robed Seneca chief in a silk turban ...
answer: entering with four Huron braves. This is not the Magua we saw on the trail. In his scalp lock, now red-stained and cut to a Huron roach, are three blacl plumes. A match-coat blanket drapes his left shoulder.

question: For my children and the children of the true faith, my friendship and esteem is boundless ... I will give you three oxen for a feast and tomorrow I, myself, will sing the war song with you in the great council house. Le Renard Subtil, how are things with your English friends? Louis Antoine, join us. Hear what le Subtil has to tell us ...
answer: English war chief, Webb goes to Fort Edward with 33rd Regiment. He does not know my father's army attacks Fort William Henry. The Grey Hair will try. The Grey Hair's children were under Magua's knife but escaped. They'll be under it again.

question: Why do hate the Grey Hair, Magua?
answer: When the Grey Hair is dead, Magua will eat his heart. Before he dies Magua will put his children under the knife so the Grey Hair will see his seed is wiped out forever.

question: She know what she's doin'? She does not shy away from much ... Nothin'. enters. Cora's sewing up Uncas.
answer: Mr Poe?

question: Miss. May I? You 'bout done holdin' hands with Miss Munro?
answer: What are you looking at, Mr. Poe?

question: Sergeant! Form three ranks!
answer: Sir! Upon the center, wheel to the left-about! March! Rear ranks, proper distance! Front ranks, take your distance! March! Halt! Make ready! First rank! Second rank! Present arms!

question: Fire!!! Advance, Sergeant Major!
answer: Sir!!! Third rank! Twelve paces! Forward march! Shoulder arms! Present!

question: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to ...
answer: Her nerves are shattered. She's trying to be brave.

question: Cora, I adore you and, when we come together, we will be the happiest couple in England ... I am certain of that. More than ever before. I believe you must trust the judgment of others who hold your welfare so close to their hearts ...
answer: Duncan ... Duncan, I promised you an answer. You have complimented me with your persistence and patience ... But the decision I've come to is I'd rather make the gravest of mistakes than surrender my own judgment. And it's been unfair to you, while I search myself for feelings, which, if they were there and as strong as they ought to be, would've made themselves known long ago ... Take my admiration and friendship, Duncan. And please take this as my final answer. It must be no.

question: I see ...
answer: I am sorry, Duncan ...

question: You forget yourself!
answer: We are not forgettin' Webb's promise!

question: British promises are honored. And the militia will not be released. Because I need more definite proof than this man's word!
answer: Nathaniel's word been good on the frontier a long time before you got here!

question: This interview's over! The militia stays!
answer: Does the rule of English law no longer govern? Has it been replaced by absolutism?

question: And if English law cannot be trusted, maybe these people would do better makin' a peace with the French!
answer: That is sedition! Treason!

question: That is the truth!
answer: I ought to have you whipped from this fort!

question: I believe if they set aside their law as and when they wish, their law no longer has rightful authority over us. All they have over us is tyranny, then. And I'll stay here no longer. No force on earth will keep me here ... Anyone caught leavin' the fort could be shot. So each man make your own decision ... Those who are goin', be back here in an hour.
answer: Out the northern sally-port. Strike for the east side of the swamp until you clear the French picket line. Head north over the ridge, then come about southeast and fork left in Little Meadow and you're free of the outpost and skirmishers ... I'll cover them from the top of the casement.

question: You're not coming with us?
answer: Got a reason to stay.

question: That reason wear a blue dress and work in the surgery?
answer: It does and it is a better lookin' reason than you, Jack Winthrop. Push hard, 'cos you got to clear the French outpost by dawn. Good luck, Jack.

question: Duncan, you are a man with a few admirable qualities. But taken as a whole, I was wrong to have thought so highly of you.
answer: But the man is guilty of sedition and subject to military justice and beyond pardon.

question: "Justice"? If that's "justice" ..., then the sooner French guns blow the English army out of America, the better it will be for these people.
answer: You do not know what you are saying!

question: Yes I do! I know exactly what I am saying. And if it is sedition, then I am guilty of sedition, too!
answer: Sorry ... can't ask you in.

question: They're going to hang you. Why didn't you leave when you had the chance?
answer: Because what I am interested in is right here ...

question: What would you have me do?
answer: Webb's reinforcements will arrive or not. If they do not arrive, the fort will fall. If that happens, stay close to your father. The French will protect the officer class among the English.

question: No. I will find you.
answer: Do not. Promise me.

question: The whole world's on fire, isn't it?
answer: This part of it sure is ...

question: What is it?
answer: I don't know. Whatever happens you stay with your father. You stay among the officers.

question: Colonel Munro, I have known you as a gallant antagonist. I am happy to make your acquaintance as a friend.
answer: And I to make yours, Monsieur le Marquis.

question: Please accept my compliments for the strong and skillful defense of your fortress. Under the command of a lesser man it would have fallen long ago given the superior numbers and material ... mere chance has allowed me to array against you ...
answer: Monsieur le Marquis, I am a soldier, not a diplomat. You called this parlay for a reason.

question: You have already done everything which is necessary for the honor of your Prince. I will forever bear testimony that your resistance has been gallant and was continued as long as there was hope. But now, I beg you to listen to the admonitions of humanity. I beg you to consider my terms for your surrender.
answer: However I may apprise such testimony from Monsieur Montcalm, Fort William Henry is strong and stands.

question: Honor that is freely accorded to courage, may be refused obstinacy ... These hills afford to us every opportunity to reconnoiter your works and I am possibly as well acquainted with your weak condition as you are yourselves.
answer: Perhaps the General's glasses can reach to the Hudson and he knows the size and imminence of the army of Webb ...?

question: You have heard your answer, Monsieur le Marquis.
answer: Sir. I am incapable of mistreating brave men. I beg you not to sign the death warrant of so many until you have listened to my terms.

question: Such as ...?
answer: My master requires the fort be destroyed. But, for you and your comrades, there is no privilege that will be denied. None of your men will see the inside of a prison barge. They're free to go so long as they return to England and fight no more on this continent, and the civilian militia return to their farms.

question: Their arms?
answer: They may leave the fortress fully armed, but with no ammunition ... Other than that, ask what you wish.

question: The honors of war?
answer: Granted.

question: My colors?
answer: Carry them to England to your King with pride.

question: Allow me to consult with my officers. I have lived to see two things I never expected. An Englishman afraid to support a friend. And a Frenchman too honest to profit by that advantage.
answer: General Webb can burn in hell. We'll go back and dig our graves behind the ramparts! Our mission is to fight.

question: Death and honor are sometimes thought to be the same. Today I have learned that they are not.
answer: Sir!

question: Granted, Monsieur. France. La victoire. Il est necessaire d'etre vigilant, mon enfant.
answer: Is the hatchet buried between the English and my French father?

question: Yes.
answer: Not a warrior has a scalp and the white men become friends.

question: My master owns these lands and your father has been ordered to drive off the English squatters. They have consented to go. So now he calls them enemies no longer.
answer: Magua took the hatchet to color it with blood. It is still bright. Only when it is red, then it will be buried.

question: But so many suns have set since Le Renard struck the war post. Is he not tired?
answer: Where is that sun?! It has gone behind the hill. It is dark and cold. It has set on his people, they are fooled and kill all the animals and sell all of their lands to enrich the European masters who are always greedy for more than they need. And Le Subtil is the son of his tribe. There have been many clouds and many mountains. But now he has come to lead his nation.

question: That Le Renard has the power to lead his people into the light, I know well.
answer: Does my father know that?

question: That's where a lead bullet has torn you.
answer: And this?

question: My son has been sadly injured. Who did this?
answer: Magua slept hard in the English wigwams. And the sticks left their mark ... Magua's village and lodges were burnt. Magua's children were killed by the English. Magua was taken as a slave by the Mohawks who fought for the Grey Hair. Magua's wife believed he was dead and became the wife of another. The Grey Hair was the father of all this. In time Magua became blood-brother to Mohawk to become free. In his heart he always was Huron. And his heart will be whole again on the day when the Grey Hair and all his seed are dead!

question: My son Magua's pain is my pain.
answer: Does the chief of the Canadas believe the English will keep the terms?

question: Munro would. But General Webb will not send their soldiers across the salt lake. Having let them go, I fear I will only fight the same men again when I move south. And yet, I cannot break the terms of the capitulation and sully the lilies of France ...
answer: Many things my French father cannot do, Magua can.

question: As the English march away, our soldiers and the Canadiens will be drawn to the looting of the fort ... except for a small guard ...
answer: I wonder at the blindness and pride of the white man. He believes only he knows how to speak falsely to make other men do his bidding.

question: shouting orders.
answer: Right - about face! March! First rank present!

question: Fire!
answer: Prime! Load! Second rank six paces forward! Present!

question: When you fall into British hands again, Nathaniel Poe, I will have you hanged.
answer: looks to Uncas. They both realize the same thing. Hawkeye nods and he, Uncas & Chingachgook begin to paddle furiously. The others match the doubled pace. They're sprinting ahead but the effort is exhausting. Pull!

question: How long?
answer: Only chance we got is ... ... to get more distance on 'em and go to ground! Pull!! Pull ...! Head for ... for the white water.

question: crawls forward and makes the island. Then the two Redcoats. Finally Uncas. The canoe rockets over the falls. Meanwhile ... Where do we go from here?
answer: We don't.

question: I don't understand!
answer: This is it, as far as we can go ... If we're lucky, they'll be figurin' we can't have come this way and must've beached our canoes and headed cross land. If we're very lucky, they'll figure we went over the falls.

question: Then what?
answer: Then we take the south rim down the mountain and it's 12 miles cross country to Fort Edward.

question: And if we're unlucky?
answer: You will have to forego the pleasure of hangin' me.

question: is soaked to the bones. Hawkeye strips off his buckskin hunting shirt and wrings it out. Cora turns her back, strips off her white blouse and puts on the faster-drying chamois. Are we safe?
answer: Maybe ...

question: Our father? Did you see my father? Tell me!
answer: Leads her to a depression, his arm around her shoulders, her face covered and she cries softly into his shoulder.

question: You try. With all you have. To save yourself. If the worst happens, and only one of us survives, something of the other does, too ...
answer: If they don't kill you, they may take you north up into Canada. A warrior may take you for a wife.

question: turns aside. Hawkeye insists.
answer: Listen. Submit. You hear me? You're strong. You stay alive. I will find you ... no matter how far, how long it takes ...

question: badly beaten, bound, staggers ahead to get behind Maqua. Then: If Magua give women to Yengeese soldiers ... will receive many gifts.
answer: Gifts?

question: Three, four oxen ... much wampum.
answer: Wampum?

question: Yes.
answer: Does Yengeese Major have property across salt sea?

question: Yes.
answer: Yengeese Major give all property to Magua. Magua give Yengeese Major much wampum, many gifts, maybe three, four oxen.

question: Gold could be arranged.
answer: For Munro children?

question: Yes.
answer: How much gold has the master of the Yengeese?

question: The King? The King has mountains of gold!
answer: Not enough.

question: What is enough?
answer: Heart. Give Magua new heart. is imperturbable.

question: Translate for me, Major. Into French. Every word ... as I say it. I come to you unarmed and in peace to unstop your ears, wise one. Because the Hurons are mislead by the words of the wolf who's never spoken the truth. Let the children of the dead Colonel Munro go free and take the fire out of the English anger over the murder of their helpless ones.
answer: Our father, Montcalm, is greater than the Yengeese in the arts of war. The Huron do not fear English anger.

question: Wise one, the French fathers made peace and swore to their honor not to break the friendship. Magua broke it. It is false that the French would not be friends, still, to the Huron.
answer: It made our French father happy to never have to fight the same Yengeese again. He told me this without telling me this.

question: So the Huron are the servants of the French? To do what the French are shamed to do?
answer: No. Huron serve no one. The French father believes he fooled Magua because he is so proud of his cleverness, he is blind. But it is the Huron path that Magua walks down, not the French one ... Now, Les Francais, also, fear Huron. That is good. When the Huron is strong from their fear, we will make the terms of trade with Les Francais. And we will trade as the white man trades. Take land from the Abnakes; fur from the Osage, Sauk & Fox. And make the Huron great. Over other tribes. No less than the whites, as strong as the whites.

question: Magua would use the ways of Les Francais and the Yengeese ...
answer: The red man put down the bow, picked up the fire stick and became the best warrior in the forest. Yes. It is the only way.

question: Would the Huron make his Algonquin brothers foolish with brandy and steal his lands to sell them for gold to the white man? Would the Huron have greed for more land than a man can use? Like Francais Black Robes do? Would Huron kill tribes with disease? Would the Huron fool Seneca into taking all the animals in the forest for beads & brandy? But sell the fur to the white man for gold? ... Those are the ways of Yengeese and Les Francais masters. Are they the ways of Huron men who hunt & work the land? Or of dogs? ... Magua's heart is twisted. He would make himself into what twisted him. A Dog, become Master of Dogs. But are Hurons dogs? ... Magua's way is false. It is like the white sickness. Magua's way will bring only sadness and shame. Is there another way? I don't know. I am Nathaniel of the Yengeese; Hawkeye, adopted son of Chingachgook, of the Mohican people ... Let the children of the dead Munro go free ... I speak the truth.
answer: waits for the decision.

question: charging Chingachgook.
answer: isn't there. He rolled and, on one knee with his back to Magua, his arm slams rearward. The massive war club crashes into Magua's back.

question: stunned, turns to hatchet Chingachgook ...
answer: now up and towering - slams his club right into Magua's assault ... destroying it, breaking Magua's right arm. And ... ... with his momentum, spins like a shot-putter and the next blow cripples Magua's left side and crushes part of his chest.

question: amazed. His body is broken and crippled, but he still stands. He looks into the eyes of the last warrior of the Mohicans.
answer: UNCAS!!!

question: is standing, her back to us, in front of a rock-covered grave with a wooden cross. Next to it is Uncas' burial platform. Cora silent prayer. Then she pauses, crosses herself. Her emotions are spent. She moves next to Hawkeye. He takes her hand.
answer: Will you go back to England?

question: I have nothing to go back for.
answer: Then will you stay in America? And will you be my wife?

question: Yes. Where will we go?
answer: Winter with the Delaware, my father's cousins. And in the spring, cross the Ohio and look for land to settle with my father in a new place called Can-tuck-ee.
